meanings.def: either of the two organs on the face that you see with
examples: The suspect has dark hair and green eyes.
to close/open your eyes
to lower your eyes (= to look down)
She rolled her eyes in disgust.
Keep your eyes shut!
in somebody's eyes/eye There were tears in his eyes.
I have something in my eye.
She had a haunted look in her dark eyes.
His eyes filled with tears.
The ending was so sad it brought tears to my eyes.
I could see a pair of blue eyes peering out at me.
Her eyes widened in disbelief.
His eyes narrowed suspiciously.
Their eyes lit up when they saw all the presents.
to make/avoid eye contact with somebody (= to look/avoid looking at them at the same time as they look at you)
All eyes were on him (= everyone was looking at him) as he walked on to the stage.
a feast/treat/delight for the eyes
As my eyes accustomed to the darkness, I could make out a shape by the window.
He drew the curtains to make sure no prying eyes saw what he was doing.
He held up the newspaper to shield his eyes from the sun.
He let his eyes roam around the scene.
He looked at me with a twinkle in his eye.
He turned his eyes to the door when he heard the handle turning.
Her bleary eyes showed that she hadn't slept.
Her eyes danced with amusement.
Her eyes dilated with horror at what she had done.
Her eyes flew open in surprise.
Her eyes glazed over when I said I worked in dictionaries.
Her eyes prickled with unshed tears.
Her eyes squinted against the brightness.
His eyes blazed with menace.
Her eyes told me nothing.
His eyes bulged in fury.
His eyes crinkled up at the corners as he smiled.
His eyes darted from face to face.
His eyes drifted over to Helen's chair.
His eyes hardened as he remembered how they had laughed at him.
His eyes held a mischievous gleam.
His eyes never left mine.
His eyes reflected his anguish.
His eyes rounded in mock amazement.
His eyes were drawn to a bundle of papers in the corner.
His narrow eyes betrayed his impatience.
I didn't want to strain my eyes to read, so I put the light on.
If I hadn't seen his jump with my own eyes, I would never have believed it possible.
It is essential to wear some form of eye protection.
My eyes followed his every move.
My eyes strained to make anything out in the darkness.
My eyes stream when I chop onions.
My eyes took in every detail as I entered the house for the first time in twenty years.
Out of the corner of her eye, she saw Harry start forward.
She averted her eyes from his face.
She could feel the old lady's eyes bore into her.
She just looked at me with those big blue eyes of hers.
She laughed, her eyes alight with excitement.
She reached up and tried to gouge her attacker's eyes.
She responded softly, her eyes showing concern.
She tried to sit up, her eyes fixed on Jean's face.
Skiers wear goggles to protect their eyes from the sun.
The dog's hungry eyes were on my sandwich.
The sun was in my eyes and I couldn't see the road.
Their eyes locked together in a battle of wills.
Tina squeezed her eyes shut and bit her lip.

meanings.def: having the type or number of eyes mentioned
examples: a blue-eyed blonde
a one-eyed monster

meanings.def: the ability to see
examples: A surgeon needs a good eye and a steady hand.
Her skill at working with wood is coupled to a keen eye for design.

meanings.def: a particular way of seeing something
examples: with the eye of somebody He looked at the design with the eye of an engineer.
with a… eye She viewed the findings with a critical eye.
to somebody's eye To my eye, the windows seem out of proportion.
To an expert eye, the painting is an obvious fake.
He saw his students with new eyes now that he had a child of his own.
You need to look at your website through the user's eyes.

meanings.def: the hole in the end of a needle that you put the thread through
a small thin piece of metal curved round, that a small hook fits into, used for fastening clothes
examples: It fastens with a hook and eye.

meanings.def: a calm area at the centre of a storm, etc.
a dark mark on a potato from which another plant will grow
a person or thing that is loved more than any other
examples: She is the apple of her father's eye.

meanings.def: to the horizon (= where the sky meets the land or sea)
examples: The bleak moorland stretched on all sides as far as the eye could see.

meanings.def: to open and close your eyes quickly, in a way that is supposed to be attractive
to be watching somebody/something carefully and with a lot of interest
examples: The kids were all eyes as he slowly unwrapped the package.

meanings.def: people all have different ideas about what is beautiful
in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody
examples: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.

meanings.def: to have a lot of something to deal with
examples: We're up to our eyes in work.

meanings.def: a view of something from a high position looking down
examples: From the plane we had a bird's-eye view of Manhattan.

meanings.def: to look at or examine something quickly
examples: Could you just run your eyes over this report?
I cast my eyes around the room but couldn't see any familiar faces.

meanings.def: to attract somebody’s attention
examples: Can you catch the waiter's eye?

meanings.def: to see somebody/something
examples: I haven't clapped eyes on them for weeks.
I hope I never set eyes on this place again!
Tom fell in love the moment he laid eyes on her.

meanings.def: to look at or listen to something/somebody carefully and with a lot of attention
pleasant to listen to or look at
examples: The room was painted in soft pastels that were easy on the eye.

meanings.def: pleasant to look at
examples: The room was painted in soft pastels that were easy on the eye.

meanings.def: used to show that you do not believe somebody/something
examples: ‘It's an antique.’ ‘An antique, my eye!’

meanings.def: used to say that you should punish somebody by doing to them what they have done to you or to somebody else
examples: They advocate a justice system that works on the principle of an eye for an eye.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to look at somebody/something and get great pleasure
to be seen only by a particular person
examples: I'll lend you the letters but they're for your eyes only.

meanings.def: to practise so that you are able to make good judgements about a task or activity that you are doing
examples: I've got my eye in now—the ball is landing just where I want it.

meanings.def: to be able to judge if things look attractive, valuable, etc.
examples: I've never had much of an eye for fashion.
She has an eye for a bargain.

meanings.def: to be watching somebody carefully, especially to check that they do not do anything wrong
examples: And remember, I'll have my eye on you so you'd better behave.
The store detective had his eye on a group of boys who were acting suspiciously.

meanings.def: to be thinking about asking somebody out, offering somebody a job, etc. because you think they are attractive, good at their job, etc.
examples: He's got his eye on the new girl in your class.

meanings.def: to be thinking about buying something
to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

meanings.def: to be able to notice or see everything
examples: She's bound to notice that chipped glass. The woman has eyes like a hawk!

meanings.def: to look at or watch something while doing something else, especially in a secret way so that other people do not notice
examples: During his talk, most of the delegates had one eye on the clock.

meanings.def: to always be looking for the chance to have a new sexual relationship
to be very obvious to somebody
very quickly; in a short time
in somebody’s opinion or according to the way that they see the situation
examples: She can do no wrong in her father's eyes.
To Western eyes, it may seem that the city is overcrowded.

meanings.def: according to the law, most people in the world, etc.
examples: In the eyes of the law she is guilty, though few ordinary people would think so.
In the eyes of the law his knife was an offensive weapon.

meanings.def: well known to many people through television, newspapers, the internet, etc.
examples: She doesn't want her children growing up in the public eye.

meanings.def: very quickly
examples: Suddenly, in the twinkling of an eye, her whole life had been turned upside down.

meanings.def: to watch somebody/something carefully
examples: Over the next few months we will keep a close eye on sales.

meanings.def: to listen or look out for somebody/something that you might hear or see
to take care of somebody/something and make sure that they are not harmed, damaged, etc.
examples: We've asked the neighbours to keep an eye on the house for us while we are away.
Could you keep an eye on my bag while I go to the toilet?

meanings.def: to continue to give your attention to what is most important
to look for somebody/something while you are doing other things
examples: Police have asked residents to keep an eye out for anything suspicious.
I walked around the store, keeping an eye out for bargains.

meanings.def: to look out for somebody/something that you might see
to look out for somebody/something that you might see
examples: We kept our eyes peeled for any signs of life.

meanings.def: to watch somebody/something carefully in case you need to take action
examples: Keep a weather eye on your competitors.

meanings.def: to look straight at somebody without feeling embarrassed or ashamed
examples: Can you look me in the eye and tell me you're not lying?
She looked her father straight in the eye and answered his question truthfully.
I'll never be able to look her in the face again!

meanings.def: to look at somebody in a way that shows that you find them sexually attractive
examples: He's definitely giving you the eye!

meanings.def: if you meet somebody’s eye(s), you look directly at them as they look at you; if two people’s eyes meet, they look directly at each other
examples: She was afraid to meet my eye.
Their eyes met across the crowded room.
She met his gaze without flinching.

meanings.def: if a sight meets your eyes, you see it
examples: A terrible sight met their eyes.

meanings.def: your imagination
examples: He pictured the scene in his mind's eye.

meanings.def: the normal power of your eyes without the help of an instrument
examples: The planet should be visible with/to the naked eye.

meanings.def: to show no surprise or concern when something unusual happens
examples: She didn't bat an eyelid when I told her my news.

meanings.def: to be very surprised at something you hear/see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

meanings.def: to be very surprised at something you see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

meanings.def: used to say that everyone was very emotional about something
examples: There wasn't a dry eye in the house when they announced their engagement.

meanings.def: to not share the same views as somebody about something
examples: The two of them have never seen eye to eye on politics.

meanings.def: to find somebody/something so interesting, attractive, etc. that you watch them all the time
examples: He couldn't keep his eyes off the girl sitting opposite him.

meanings.def: a result, action, etc. that is disappointing or a defeat for somebody/something
examples: The appointment of a woman was one in the eye for male domination.

meanings.def: to be in love with only one particular person
examples: He's only ever had eyes for his wife.

meanings.def: to realize or make somebody realize the truth about something
examples: Travelling really opens your eyes to other cultures.

meanings.def: to be very attractive to look at
to hide your real actions or intentions from somebody by making them believe something that is not true
to think about or see something the way that another person sees it
examples: Try looking at it through her eyes for a change.
Events are seen through the eyes of a Polish refugee.

meanings.def: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it
examples: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

meanings.def: to pretend that you have not noticed something so that you do not have to deal with it
examples: You can't just close your eyes to his violence.
They seem intent on shutting their eyes to the problems of pollution.

meanings.def: a person or thing that you are pleased to see; something that is very pleasant to look at
to stop giving your attention to what is most important
a person or thing is more complicated or interesting than you might think at first
to pretend not to notice something bad that is happening, so you do not have to do anything about it
examples: The authorities were either unaware of the problem or they turned a blind eye to it.

meanings.def: being watched carefully by somebody
examples: The children played under the watchful eye of their father.
I want you under my eye.

meanings.def: if a person does not know about something that they would normally think was bad, then it cannot hurt them
examples: What does it matter if I use his flat while he’s away? What the eye doesn’t see…!

meanings.def: with the hope of using a particular situation in order to gain some advantage for yourself
fully aware of the possible problems or results of a particular course of action
examples: I went into this with my eyes open so I guess I only have myself to blame.

meanings.def: very easily, without thinking about it
examples: I've made this trip so often, I could do it with my eyes shut.

meanings.def: with the intention of doing something
examples: He bought the warehouse with an eye to converting it into a hotel.

idioms.def: a person or thing that is loved more than any other
examples: She is the apple of her father's eye.

idioms.idiom: as far as the eye can/could see
idioms.def: to the horizon (= where the sky meets the land or sea)
examples: The bleak moorland stretched on all sides as far as the eye could see.

idioms.def: to open and close your eyes quickly, in a way that is supposed to be attractive
to be watching somebody/something carefully and with a lot of interest
examples: The kids were all eyes as he slowly unwrapped the package.

idioms.idiom: beauty is in the eye of the beholder
idioms.def: people all have different ideas about what is beautiful
in somebody’s presence; in front of somebody
examples: He had seen his life's work destroyed before his very eyes.
Before our very eyes, the bird snatched the fish from the plate and flew off.

idioms.idiom: be up to your eyes in something

examples: We're up to our eyes in work.

idioms.def: a view of something from a high position looking down

idioms.def: to look at or examine something quickly

I cast my eyes around the room but couldn't see any familiar faces.

idioms.def: to attract somebody’s attention

idioms.def: to see somebody/something

I hope I never set eyes on this place again!
Tom fell in love the moment he laid eyes on her.

idioms.def: to look at or listen to something/somebody carefully and with a lot of attention
pleasant to listen to or look at
examples: The room was painted in soft pastels that were easy on the eye.

idioms.def: pleasant to look at

idioms.def: used to show that you do not believe somebody/something
examples: ‘It's an antique.’ ‘An antique, my eye!’

examples: They advocate a justice system that works on the principle of an eye for an eye.

idioms.idiom: somebody’s eyes are bigger than their stomach
idioms.def: used to say that somebody has been greedy by taking more food than they can eat
to look at somebody/something and get great pleasure
to be seen only by a particular person
examples: I'll lend you the letters but they're for your eyes only.

idioms.def: to practise so that you are able to make good judgements about a task or activity that you are doing
examples: I've got my eye in now—the ball is landing just where I want it.

idioms.def: to be able to judge if things look attractive, valuable, etc.
examples: I've never had much of an eye for fashion.
She has an eye for a bargain.

idioms.def: to be watching somebody carefully, especially to check that they do not do anything wrong
examples: And remember, I'll have my eye on you so you'd better behave.
The store detective had his eye on a group of boys who were acting suspiciously.
He's got his eye on the new girl in your class.

idioms.def: to be thinking about buying something

idioms.idiom: have eyes in the back of your head
idioms.def: to be aware of everything that is happening around you, even things that seem difficult or impossible to see
examples: You can’t get away with anything in her class. She has eyes in the back of her head.

idioms.def: to be able to notice or see everything
examples: She's bound to notice that chipped glass. The woman has eyes like a hawk!

idioms.def: to look at or watch something while doing something else, especially in a secret way so that other people do not notice
examples: During his talk, most of the delegates had one eye on the clock.

idioms.def: to always be looking for the chance to have a new sexual relationship
to be very obvious to somebody

idioms.idiom: in the blink of an eye
idioms.def: very quickly; in a short time
in somebody’s opinion or according to the way that they see the situation
examples: She can do no wrong in her father's eyes.
To Western eyes, it may seem that the city is overcrowded.

idioms.idiom: in the eyes of the law, world, etc.
idioms.def: according to the law, most people in the world, etc.
examples: In the eyes of the law she is guilty, though few ordinary people would think so.
In the eyes of the law his knife was an offensive weapon.

idioms.def: well known to many people through television, newspapers, the internet, etc.
examples: She doesn't want her children growing up in the public eye.

idioms.idiom: in the twinkling of an eye
idioms.def: very quickly
examples: Suddenly, in the twinkling of an eye, her whole life had been turned upside down.

idioms.idiom: keep a close eye/watch on somebody/something
idioms.def: to watch somebody/something carefully
examples: Over the next few months we will keep a close eye on sales.

idioms.def: to listen or look out for somebody/something that you might hear or see
to take care of somebody/something and make sure that they are not harmed, damaged, etc.
examples: We've asked the neighbours to keep an eye on the house for us while we are away.
Could you keep an eye on my bag while I go to the toilet?

idioms.idiom: keep your eye on the ball
idioms.def: to continue to give your attention to what is most important
to look for somebody/something while you are doing other things
examples: Police have asked residents to keep an eye out for anything suspicious.
I walked around the store, keeping an eye out for bargains.

idioms.def: to look out for somebody/something that you might see
to look out for somebody/something that you might see
examples: We kept our eyes peeled for any signs of life.

idioms.idiom: keep a weather eye on somebody/something
idioms.def: to watch somebody/something carefully in case you need to take action
examples: Keep a weather eye on your competitors.

idioms.def: to look straight at somebody without feeling embarrassed or ashamed
examples: Can you look me in the eye and tell me you're not lying?
She looked her father straight in the eye and answered his question truthfully.
I'll never be able to look her in the face again!

idioms.idiom: make eyes at somebody | give somebody the eye
idioms.def: to look at somebody in a way that shows that you find them sexually attractive
examples: He's definitely giving you the eye!

idioms.idiom: meet somebody’s eye(s) | meet somebody’s gaze, look, etc. | people’s eyes meet
idioms.def: if you meet somebody’s eye(s), you look directly at them as they look at you; if two people’s eyes meet, they look directly at each other
examples: She was afraid to meet my eye.
Their eyes met across the crowded room.
She met his gaze without flinching.
A terrible sight met their eyes.

idioms.def: your imagination
examples: He pictured the scene in his mind's eye.

idioms.def: the normal power of your eyes without the help of an instrument
examples: The planet should be visible with/to the naked eye.

idioms.def: to show no surprise or concern when something unusual happens
examples: She didn't bat an eyelid when I told her my news.

idioms.def: to be very surprised at something you hear/see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

idioms.def: to be very surprised at something you see
examples: I couldn't believe my eyes when she walked in.

idioms.idiom: not a dry eye in the house
idioms.def: used to say that everyone was very emotional about something
examples: There wasn't a dry eye in the house when they announced their engagement.

idioms.idiom: not see eye to eye with somebody (on something)
idioms.def: to not share the same views as somebody about something
examples: The two of them have never seen eye to eye on politics.

idioms.idiom: not (be able to) take your eyes off somebody/something
idioms.def: to find somebody/something so interesting, attractive, etc. that you watch them all the time
examples: He couldn't keep his eyes off the girl sitting opposite him.

idioms.def: a result, action, etc. that is disappointing or a defeat for somebody/something
examples: The appointment of a woman was one in the eye for male domination.

idioms.idiom: only have eyes for/have eyes only for somebody
idioms.def: to be in love with only one particular person
examples: He's only ever had eyes for his wife.

idioms.def: to realize or make somebody realize the truth about something
examples: Travelling really opens your eyes to other cultures.

idioms.def: to be very attractive to look at

idioms.idiom: pull the wool over somebody’s eyes
idioms.def: to hide your real actions or intentions from somebody by making them believe something that is not true

idioms.idiom: see, look at, etc. something through somebody’s eyes
idioms.def: to think about or see something the way that another person sees it
examples: Try looking at it through her eyes for a change.
Events are seen through the eyes of a Polish refugee.

idioms.idiom: see something out of the corner of your eye
idioms.def: to see something by accident or not very clearly because you see it from the side of your eye and are not looking straight at it
examples: Out of the corner of her eye, she saw him coming closer.

idioms.def: to pretend that you have not noticed something so that you do not have to deal with it
examples: You can't just close your eyes to his violence.
They seem intent on shutting their eyes to the problems of pollution.

idioms.def: a person or thing that you are pleased to see; something that is very pleasant to look at

idioms.idiom: take your eye off the ball
idioms.def: to stop giving your attention to what is most important

idioms.idiom: there is more to somebody/something than meets the eye
idioms.def: a person or thing is more complicated or interesting than you might think at first
to pretend not to notice something bad that is happening, so you do not have to do anything about it
examples: The authorities were either unaware of the problem or they turned a blind eye to it.

idioms.def: being watched carefully by somebody
examples: The children played under the watchful eye of their father.
I want you under my eye.

idioms.idiom: what the eye doesn’t see (the heart doesn’t grieve over)
idioms.def: if a person does not know about something that they would normally think was bad, then it cannot hurt them
examples: What does it matter if I use his flat while he’s away? What the eye doesn’t see…!

idioms.idiom: with an eye for/on/to the main chance
idioms.def: with the hope of using a particular situation in order to gain some advantage for yourself
fully aware of the possible problems or results of a particular course of action
examples: I went into this with my eyes open so I guess I only have myself to blame.

idioms.def: very easily, without thinking about it
examples: I've made this trip so often, I could do it with my eyes shut.

idioms.idiom: with an eye to something/to doing something
idioms.def: with the intention of doing something
examples: He bought the warehouse with an eye to converting it into a hotel.

meanings.def: to look at somebody/something carefully, especially because you want something or you suspect that something is wrong
examples: to eye somebody suspiciously
He couldn't help eyeing the cakes hungrily.
They eyed us with alarm.
The children eyed the cakes greedily.
